head.title: Journal of a Passage in a Canoe from Pais Plat in Lake Superior to Portage de l'Isle in River Ouinipique, 1784. - Page #5

body.p: << First Page | < Previous Page | Page #5 of 32 | Next Page > | Last Page >>

td.p: Umfreville, Edward. Journal of a Passage in a Canoe from Pais Plat in Lake Superior to Portage de l'Isle in River Ouinipique, 1784. An electronic transcription. MFTP #0030

div.p: June 16 Wednesday[.] At 11a.m. parted Company with Mr Grant, having an Indian guide to pilot us to Lake Nippigon. 1st Course from the East end of an Island at the mouth of the River Païs Plat, to a point NWbW 3 miles – WbN9m. to a Creek call'd by the Indians Na-ab-be-cou – then WNW across a Bay 2m. – WbN6m. – over a bay to the Wt pt of an island Wt10m. another island of high land laying on its So side – WbN4m – then WbN2m. across a small bay – on approaching the last point the water changes to a sandy colour, & becomes Shoaly – WNW¾m. – NWbW½m – NNW2½ – the beginning of the last Course may be call'd ye commencement of River Nippigon, & both Shores run pretty regular No & So[,] a isld lays off the mouth of the River dist. abt 2m. – both Shores are perpendicular & rocky, & the River is abt 1m. wide.

17 Thursday. We had proceeded but a short distance this day before we found the River very shallow, not having above 2 foot water in several places, but the bottom is sandy & Currt gentle. At the end of the last mentd Course the River appears to be entirely clos'd by woods, but on a nearer approa[ch] a passage opens between a high sandy bank & the point of an Islet – NN[E]¼m, shoaly on ye Et side & sandy stony bottom, & strong Currt pass'd on the Wt or left side – then a rapid stony & shoaly, here the men debark'd & led the Canoes, this rapid is abt ½m. long, pass'd it with perches on the left Sid[e] then an easy Currt for abt 100yds – then came to a rapid point which sent us on the other side of the River – then abt 40yds to a point – after which ye River opens wide, or is rather a small Lake, here our Guide sa[id] Sturgeon were plentiful, went in this Lake NNW3m. to a point – from hen[ce] the main branch of the River bore No – left it on the right hand & enter'[d] the lesser branch, the mouth of which is shoaly, sandy bottom & driftwoo[d,] 1st Course in it NW¼m – WNbW½m – WNW½ – then round a pt N¼m. NW¼m. round a point – then NWbW1/4 m 70yds S.Current – then NWbN½[m.] No¼m. round a point – NW½ – NWbW1m – NW2 – NbW1½ pass'd a small Creek which empties itself on the Wt side with a water fall, then N½[m.] to the Portage de roche Capitaine carried over ye Goods & pass'd the canoe wth perches & Tracking line of abt 50yds in length, the Portage on the righ[t] hand side of the River – then round a bay ¼m. NbW¼m. to a rapid par[t,] Shoaly & stones above water, this rapid is ¼m. long, pass'd it on the left side of the River, the men debark'd & pass'd the Canoe with perches & Tracking line, we then left the river on our Right hand, & enter'd a small Cree[k]

td.p:
L E G E N D :
in red , modifications made by the editor(s).
in lavender , modifications made by the assumed author(s).
